leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.1] r 42.1 General rule that costs follow the event (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: General rule that costs follow the event (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 11)

p.text: Subject to this Part, if the court makes any order as to costs, the court is to order that the costs follow the event unless it appears to the court that some other order should be made as to the whole or any part of the costs.
Legislation cited in [42.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 98.

The general costs discretion conferred by CPA s 98 operates subject to the rules. The present rule provides the principle that the proper exercise of the costs at discretion will normally require an order that the successful party’s costs be paid by the unsuccessful party, at least to the extent to which their costs have been reasonably incurred in the conduct of the litigation: Latoudis v Casey (1990) 170 CLR 534 at 566–7; 97 ALR 45 at 67–8 and Oshlack v Richmond River Council (1998) 193 CLR 72 at 97; 152 ALR 83 at 101–2 ; Ritter v Godfrey [1920] 2 KB 47 ; Dodds Family Investments Pty Ltd (formerly Solar Tint Pty Ltd) v Lane Industries Pty Ltd (1993) 26 IPR 261 at 271 . The entitlement to costs arises from success on the subject matter of the proceedings and provides an additional compensatory indemnity for the vindication of the successful claim. This exercise of the costs discretion is compensatory rather than punitive: Ohn v Walton (1995) 36 NSWLR 77 at 79 per Gleeson CJ. Where there are multiple unsuccessful parties, costs ought be ordered against them jointly and severally: Ryan v South Sydney Junior Rugby League Club Ltd [1975] 2 NSWLR 660 at 663 ; Trade Practices Commission v Nicholas Enterprises Pty Ltd (No 3) (1979) 28 ALR 201 at 210; 42 FLR 213 ; Rushcutters Bay Smash Repairs Pty Ltd v H McKenna Netmakers Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 670; BC200304118 ; unless, and to the extent that, the proceedings against them involved separate and discrete issues: Mt Gambier Co-op Milling Society Ltd v Williams [1921] SASR 185 ; Thiess Watkins White Construction Ltd (in liq) v Witan Nominees (1985) Pty Ltd [1992] 2 Qd R 452 at 454.

It is generally accepted that the expression “follow the event” refers to the practical result of a particular claim: Windsurfing International Inc v Petit (1987) AIPC ¶90-441 per Waddell J. But this general acceptance inhibits a thorough understanding of the expression. It was fully considered in Reid Hewett & Co v Joseph [1918] AC 717 . That case has subsequently been treated as authoritatively determining that the “event” for the purposes of the costs discretion is not limited to the determination of either the proceedings as a whole or of particular causes of action: Williams v Stanley Jones & Co Ltd [1926] 2 KB 37 ; Jelbarts Pty Ltd v McDonald [1919] VLR 478 . It extends to any disputed question of fact or law and is not limited to “issues” in the technical pleading sense: Forster v Faruhar [1893] 1 QB 564 at 569 per Bowen LJ; Hughes v Western Australian Cricket Assn Inc (1986) ATPR ¶40-748 at 48, 136 per Toohey J; Cretazzo v Lombardi (1975) 13 SASR 4 at 12 . The expression is, therefore, one of some fluidity and, although the “general acceptance” referred to at the start of this note is an adequate approach for most purposes, there is considerable force in the observation of Thomas J in Colburt v Beard [1992] 2 Qd R 67 , that the problem of the identification of “issues” and the separation of discrete parts of proceedings for the purposes of making orders for costs has never been satisfactorily resolved.

level.toc-caption: [42.1.15] Follow the event — multiple issues, partial success

heading.title: Follow the event — multiple issues, partial success

p.text: The general proposition that successful parties are usually entitled to their costs of the proceedings and the "follow the event" rule produce different discretionary considerations where and a party succeeds on some issues and fails on others. Particular difficulty can arise where an otherwise successful party has failed succeeds on issues that occupied a substantial part of the time taken by the proceedings.

General rule — no apportionment: Ordinarily it will be appropriate to award the costs of proceedings to the successful party without attempting to differentiate between those particular issues on which it was successful and those on which it failed: Waters v PC Henderson (Aust) Pty Ltd (1994) 254 ALR 28 at 330–331; [1994] NSWCA 338 ; BC9404952 ; Alltrans Express Ltd v CVA Holdings Ltd [1984] 1 All ER 685 at 690–2; [1984] 1 WLR 394 ; Hughes v Western Australian Cricket Assn Inc (1986) ATPR ¶40-748; Australian Conservation Foundation Inc v Forestry Commission of Tasmania (1988) 76 LGRA 381; 81 ALR 166 at 169 per Burchett J (an ultimately successful party should not be put at risk as to costs merely by having relied on additional issues on which it did not succeed); Morosi v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1977] 2 NSWLR 749 at 808 ; MacKinnon v Petersen (NSWSC, Cole J, 14017/88, 19 April 1989, unreported, BC8902277) (building dispute); Yazgi v Permanent Custodians Ltd (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 306; BC200709404 at [25] (multiple issue — none of the claims inappropriately brought and did not prolong the trial — no apportionment); McLaughlin v Dungowan Manly Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 306; BC201002336 at [43] (unsuccessful claims did not add substantially to the length of hearing and were not relevant to the understanding of other matters in issue which were argued successfully — no apportionment of costs referable to separate issues).

Apportionment in appropriate cases: This ordinary principle has been criticised as unduly restricting the width of the statutory discretion (in CPA s 98) and capable of unfair operation: Probiotec Ltd v University of Melbourne (2008) 166 FCR 30; 244 ALR 96; [2008] FCAFC 5; BC200800400 ; Bowen Investments Pty Ltd v Tabcorp Holdings Ltd (No 2) [2008] FCAFC 107; BC200804480 . It is subject to qualification where the otherwise successful party failed on matters that were either the dominant issue in contest or were clearly separable from the matters on which the party succeeded: Waters v PC Henderson (Aust) Pty Ltd (1994) 254 ALR 328; [1994] NSWCA 338; BC9404952 (which approved the substance of the proposition stated in this note); Elite Protective Personel v Salmon (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 373; BC200711102 (7 grounds of appeal, 2 abandoned and 1 failed — successful party to bear 25 per cent of costs); Bostik Australia Pty Ltd v Liddiard (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 304; BC200908727 at [38] (partial success on a limitation defence — defendant ordered to pay only 40 per cent of successful party’s costs). This qualification may apply more readily to a plaintiff who has raised additional issues on which they failed, than to a successful defendant who reasonably raised additional, but unsuccessful, defences: Griffith v Australian Broadcasting Corp (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 145; BC201103885 at [19]–[20] and [38]–[39].

Separate costs orders may also be made in relation to issues that a party unreasonably pursued: Oshlack v Richmond River Council (1998) 193 CLR 72 at 122; 152 ALR 83; [1998] HCA 11; BC9800310 . They may also be made in relation to issues where a party behaved improperly in the conduct of the proceedings: Jamal v Secretary Department of Health (1988) 14 NSWLR 252 at 271; (1988) EOC 92-234 . But neither unreasonable behaviour nor improper conduct of the otherwise successful party are necessary to justify moderating a costs order to reflect a party’s failure on particular issues: Permanent Trustee Australia Ltd v FAI General Insurance Co Ltd (SC(NSW), Hodgson CJ in Eq, 3 June 1998, unreported, BC9802305) at [10]–[11]; Short v Crawley (No 40) [2008] NSWSC 1302; BC200811010 at [32]; Corbett Court Pty Ltd v Quasar Constructions (NSW) Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1423; BC200812285 at [25]–[32]).

The nature of the apportionment: The assessment involved in the application of the general principle, and its acknowledged qualifications, is a matter of impressionistic discretionary evaluation. In the exercise of such a discretion mathematical precision in the appropriate apportionment of costs is not to be expected: James v Surf Road Nominees Pty Ltd (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 296; BC200506531 at [31]–[36], citing Dodds Family Investments Pty Ltd v Land Industries Pty Ltd (1993) 26 IPR 261; BC9304823 ; Bostik Australia Pty Ltd v Liddiard (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 304; BC200908727 at [38]; Sydney Ferries v Morton (No 2) [2010] NSWCA 238; BC201006768 at [10]. It will rarely be appropriate to attempt to support an application for a special costs order in relation to particular issues by a minutely detailed quantification of the scope of the affidavits, oral evidence and submissions related to particular issues: Tomanovic v Global Mortgage Equity Corporation Pty Ltd (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 256; BC201106550 at [84].

Examples of apportionment: Notwithstanding the difficulty of prescribing anything other than general considerations for the exercise of the discretion to depart from the “ordinary” principle, there are numerous instances where a court has deprived an otherwise successful party of costs in relation to particular matters. A clearly non-exhaustive illustration of such instances includes the following: Fexuto Pty Ltd v Bosnjak Holdings Pty Ltd (No 3) (1998) 30 ACSR 20; BC9806555 (plaintiff awarded half costs after failing on some issues); NRMA Ltd v Morgan (No 3) [1999] NSWSC 768; BC9904387 (defendant ordered to pay two thirds of the plaintiff’s costs); Ledgerwood v Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd (No 2) (NSWSC, Young J, 3818/95, 25 August 1997, unreported, BC9704806); Dao v Nguyen (NSWSC, McLelland CJ, 3943/96, 25 August 1997, unreported, BC9703847) (Eq Div); Mok Gek Bouy v Minister for Immigration, Local Govt and Ethnic Affairs (No 2) (1993) 47 FCR 81; BC9305172 (90 per cent of costs allowed where applicant failed on some issues); Rosniak v Government Insurance Office (1997) 41 NSWLR 608 at 615; 26 MVR 204; (1997) Aust Torts Reports 81-440; BC9702453 (indemnity costs ordered where the plaintiff failed on an attempt to challenge High Court authority on a particular issue governing the award of damages): Butcher v Lachlan Elder Realty Pty Ltd (2002) 55 NSWLR 558; 11 BPR 20,317; [2002] NSWCA 237; BC200204907 at [92] citing Parker v McKenna (1874) LR10ChApp 96 at 125; [1874-80] All ER Rep 443 (unnecessary fraud allegation against a solicitor).

level.toc-caption: [42.1.20] Follow the event — discretion to refuse costs to a successful party

heading.title: Follow the event — discretion to refuse costs to a successful party

p.text: A court may depart from the general principle that costs follow the event if it is satisfied “some other order should be made”. A court may, in appropriate circumstances, either order costs against, or merely refrain from ordering costs in favour of, a successful party: Donald Campbell & Co Ltd v Pollak [1927] AC 732 (withholding of evidence by the successful party); Knight v Clifton [1971] Ch 700 ; Cretazzo v Lombardi (1975) 13 SASR 4 ; Laguillo v Haden Engineering Pty Ltd [1978] 1 NSWLR 306 . The generality of the true scope of the discretion permits its variable application in a wide range of circumstances. Examples include the following situations:

where a party’s success in the proceedings is attributable only to matters raised in a late amendment: Beoco Ltd v Alfa Laval Co Ltd [1995] QB 137; [1994] 4 All ER 464 (plaintiff succeeding only on issues raised in a late amendment — no costs awarded);

where the successful party recovers merely nominal damages: Alltrans Express Ltd v CVA Holdings Ltd [1984] 1 All ER 685 ; Anglo Cyprian Trade Agencies Ltd v Paphos Wine Industries Ltd [1951]1 All ER 873 (defendant entitled to costs where plaintiff awarded trivial damages);

where the proceedings are in the nature of a test case, and the successful party is a frequent litigant likely to be substantially advantaged by the favourable resolution of the particular issue: CSR Ltd v Eddy (2005) 222 ALR 1; [2005] HCA 64; BC200507889 ;

where the successful party had either encouraged the unsuccessful party to contest the proceedings, or otherwise misconducted themselves in relation to either the transaction the subject of the proceedings, or to the conduct of the proceedings: Ritter v Godfrey [1920] 2 KB 47 (intemperate correspondence from a successful defendant insufficient to justify refusal of costs). See also Sunday Times Newspaper Co Ltd v McIntosh (1933) 33 SR (NSW) 371 at 377 ; Trade Practices Commission v Nicholas Enterprises Pty Ltd (No 3) (1979) 28 ALR 201; 42 FLR 213 ; Jamal v Secretary, Dept of Health (1988) 14 NSWLR 252 at 271–2 per Mahoney JA; Trenerry v Trenerry [1966]2 NSWR 221 (impropriety by successful party though actual adultery not proved); Harnett v Vise (1880) 5 Ex D 307 (defamation — conduct by successful plaintiff inviting or contributing to defendant’s conduct); British Dominion Films Ltd v Dent [1935] VLR 157 .

level.toc-caption: [42.1.25] Follow the event — discretion to order costs against a successful party

heading.title: Follow the event — discretion to order costs against a successful party

p.text: An order that a successful party pay the costs of an unsuccessful party is generally regarded as requiring particular justification: Ottway v Jones [1955] 1 WLR 706 at 708, 714 ; Scherer v Counting Instruments Ltd [1986] 2 All ER 529 at 532; [1986] 1 WLR 615 at 618 ; Trade Practices Commission v Nicholas Enterprises Pty Ltd (No 3) (1979) 28 ALR 201; 42 FLR 213 (exceptional circumstances required); Robinson v Australian Assn of Social Workers Ltd (2000) 210 LSJS 73; [2000] SASC 239; BC200004399 . Consistent with that view, it is rare for a successful party to ordinary litigation to be ordered to pay the unsuccessful opponent's costs unless the successful party’s misconduct lengthened the proceedings unnecessarily, caused unnecessary issues to be canvassed or otherwise increased the costs of the litigation: for example in MacDougall v Curlevski (1996) 40 NSWLR 430; BC9605362 a party who succeeded in an arbitration rehearing, by relying on evidence that was not called at the arbitration, had the costs of the proceedings awarded against them on an indemnity basis. But the discretion to award costs against a successful party is not limited to conduct of this kind. The proper exercise of the discretion may also take into account the nature of the proceedings or, where the order relates to interlocutory costs, the nature of the application. In Mohamed v Farah [2004] NSWSC 598; BC200404258 the substantive application was to avoid the purported acceptance of an offer of compromise, on the ground of unilateral mistake. Despite succeeding in the application the unsuccessful defendant was awarded costs — partly because of the nature of the proceedings (the plaintiff was seeking a discretionary indulgence) and partly because of the reasonableness of putting the plaintiff to proof of the mistake. Similar orders are frequently been made against plaintiffs who succeed on applications for leave to amend and on applications for the extension of limitation periods: see Holt v Wynter (2000) 49 NSWLR 128; [2000] NSWCA 143; BC200003501 (costs order stayed pending determination of the substantive proceedings); compare Nowlan v Marson Transport Pty Ltd (2001) 53 NSWLR 116; 34 MVR 495; [2001] NSWCA 346; BC200105900 (costs of the application costs in the cause –– because the defendant failed to put the plaintiff on notice of a contested factual issue). Apart from these instances, the discretion may be capable of exercise, in an appropriate case where the misconduct relates to the successful party’s exaggeration of relevant issues and evidence: Arian v Nguyen (2001) 33 MVR 37; [2001] NSWCA 5 at [38]; BC200100266 (successful party’s deliberate exaggeration might justify an adverse costs order).

Parties may agree as to how the costs of proceedings should be borne. Sometimes that agreement may be based on the terms of the formal transaction to which the proceedings relate. For example, it is common for leases, mortgages and guarantees to contain clauses that determine both who is to bear the costs and the basis on which they are to be assessed. These contractual agreements displace the general rules that costs follow the event: see Re A Solicitor’s Bill of Costs; Re Shanahan (1941) 58 NSW (WN) 132; AGC (Advances) Ltd v West (1984) 5 NSWLR 301 ; Re Adelphi Hotel (Brighton) Ltd [1953] 2 All ER 498 ; Heaps v Addison Wesley Longman Australia Pty Ltd (2000) NSW Conv R ¶55-945; [2000] NSWSC 542; BC200003267 ; Kyabram Property Investments Pty Ltd v Murray [2005] NSWCA 87; BC200501713 at [12]–[13] (costs awarded on party/party basis even though the mortgage expressly provided for indemnity costs — claim for indemnity costs had not been pleaded in statement of claim); National Australia Bank Ltd v Chen-Conway [2008] NSWSC 485; BC200803850 (costs awarded to mortgagee on indemnity basis — relief sought expressly included costs on an indemnity basis); Lava Ltd v Avery [2009] NSWSC 237; BC200902225 (costs awarded on indemnity basis — although costs in statement of claim not pleaded in accordance with contractual basis, evident from affidavits that the claim for costs was founded on contractual entitlement). See further [42.25.5] .

Where a notice or appeal had been filed, but the appeal is incompetent a respondent to the appeal ought consider applying for an order striking out the appeal. If the appeal is later dismissed as incompetent, a respondent who did not challenge the competency of the appeal in a timely manner will not be entitled to their costs of the appeal. Conversely, a party may be deprived of their costs where, though leave to appeal is required, the appropriateness of leave should have been conceded: Gillard v Hunter Wire Products Pty Ltd (t/as Hunter Screen Products) [2001] NSWCA 450; BC200107626 at [16]–[18] citing Carolan v AMF Bowling Pty Ltd (t/as Bennetts Green Bowl) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Sheller and Cole JJA, 16 November 1995, unreported, BC9501771).

level.toc-caption: [42.1.40] Appeals — retrial and costs of the original proceedings

heading.title: Appeals — retrial and costs of the original proceedings

p.text: Where a new trial is ordered the general rule is that the costs of the first trial will follow the event of the new trial: Brittain v Commonwealth (No 2) [2004] NSWCA 427 at [30] ; Stewart v McKinley (1885) 11 VLR 802 at 809 . Alternatively, it may be appropriate to leave the costs to be determined at the re-trial: Brownlie v Overend [1979] VR 283 at 287–288 . If no specific contrary order is made on the appeal, the general rule applies and the costs of the first trial will abide the result of the retrial: Knudsen v Kara Kar Holdings Pty Ltd (No 2) (2000) 52 NSWLR 254; [2000] NSWSC 943; BC200006493 . If the new trial results principally from a party's error in the conduct of the original hearing, that consideration may justify ordering that party to pay the costs of that hearing irrespective of the outcome of the rehearing: Monaco v Arnedo Pty Ltd (1994) 13 WAR 522 . Such an order may, if the conduct of the earlier hearing involved an egregious default, be made on an indemnity basis: Brittain v Commonwealth (No 2) [2004] NSWCA 427 . Where parties succeed on a point not taken at the trial they may be deprived of their costs: Hussey v Horne-Payne (1878) 8 Ch D 670 ; Ex parte Hauxwell (1883) 23 Ch D 643. Where both parties have contributed to procedural miscarriages, the court may order each party to bear its own costs of an appeal or make no order as to costs to the intent that each party will bear its own costs of the appeal: Prokart Racing Pty Ltd (t/as Prokart Racing) v Shakya [2001] NSWCA 409; BC200107794 at [15]–[18] . See also Merrylands Bowling, Sporting and Recreation Club Ltd v P & H Property Services Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 358; BC200106176 and Damjanovic v Sharpe Hume & Co [2001] NSWCA 407; BC200107299 (both cases where the respondents' counsel contributed to procedural miscarriages).

An unsuccessful party may be ordered to pay a successful party’s costs liability to third parties. Thus, an unsuccessful plaintiff may be ordered to pay the costs of third parties joined by a successful defendant: Edginton v Clark [1964] 1 QB 367 ; Thomas v Times Book Co Ltd [1966] 2 All ER 241; [1966] 1 WLR 911 . Similarly an unsuccessful defendant’s costs liability to a plaintiff may include the plaintiff’s liability to other defendants (a “Bullock” order): Bullock v London General Omnibus Co [1907] 1 KB 264 . Alternatively an unsuccessful defendant may be ordered to pay the costs of other successful co-defendants (a “Sanderson” order): Sanderson v Blyth Theatre Co [1903] 2 KB 533 . (These examples are merely illustrative. Bullock and Sanderson type orders are not restricted to plaintiffs and defendants in the principal proceedings: Edginton v Clark , above; Thomas v Times Book Co Ltd , above, All ER at 247.)

The overriding consideration for the exercise of the discretion to make either a Bullock or a Sanderson type order is whether, as between the contending parties, it is proper to order the successful party’s costs to be paid by a particular unsuccessful party: Johnson’s Tyne Foundry Pty Ltd v Maffra Corp (1948) 77 CLR 544 at 572; [1949] ALR 89 (alternative claims against principal and agent — Bullock order made); Permanent Trustee Co Ltd v Keogh [1999] NSWSC 883 ; BC9905506 (alternative claims against solicitors and valuers — Bullock order made); Steppke v National Capital Development Commission (1978) 21 ACTR 23 (claim against road contractor and alleging vicarious liability of principal — Bullock order refused); Roads and Traffıc Authority v Snape (1999) 28 MVR 423; [1999] NSWCA 47; BC9900795 (alternative claims against road authority and nominal defendant — joinder attributable to plaintiff's inconsistent accounts — successful appeal against a Sanderson order); Altamura v Victorian Railway Cmrs [1974] VR 33 . This fundamental consideration limits the proper exercise of the discretion. But its generality leads to differences of expression and emphasis according to the circumstances of particular cases: Schipp v Cameron (NSWSC, Einstein J, No 6425/91, 12 October 1998, unreported, BC9806860) at pp 22–5. Thus it is sometimes said that the joinder of the successful third party must have been “reasonable”, or that the conduct of unsuccessful defendant must have contributed to the joinder of the successful third party: Steppke, above, at 30–1; Gould v Vaggelas (1985) 157 CLR 215 at 229, 247; 62 ALR 527 (alternative claims against vendors and accountants — Bullock order made); Fennell v Supervision and Engineering Services Holdings Pty Ltd (1988) 47 SASR 6 at 7–8 ; Lackersteen v Jones (No 2) (1988) 93 FLR 442 at 449 ). These statements should not be understood as posing disjunctive criteria: Fennell v Supervision and Engineering Services Holdings Pty Ltd , above, at 7. They serve to illustrate the basic proposition that the discretion is properly confined to cases where the respective parties claims are sufficiently related: Permanent Trustee Co Ltd v Keogh , above; Sved v Woollahra Municipal Council (1998) NSW Conv R ¶55-842; such as where they are alternative: Norwest Refrigeration Services Pty Ltd v Bain Dawes (WA) Pty Ltd (1984) 157 CLR 149; 55 ALR 509 (alternative claims against broker and insurer — Bullock order refused); or, more generally, where they are interdependent in the sense that the conduct of the unsuccessful defendant has led the plaintiff to conduct the proceedings against the third party: Gould v Vaggelas , above, CLR at 217, 229, 247; Fennell v Supervision and Engineering Services Holdings Pty Ltd , above, at 7, 15; Snyman v Cooper (1989) 24 FCR 433; 91 ALR 209 ; Goldsworthyv Brickell [1987] 1 Ch 378; [1987] 1 All ER 853 (alternative claim against solicitors prompted by affirmative defence — Sanderson order made); Coombes v Road and Traffic Authority (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 70; BC200702155 (alternative claims against road authorities — council failed to concede responsibility despite plaintiff’s request — Bullock order made); Balesfire Pty Ltd (t/as the Gutter Shop) v Adams [2006] NSWCA 112; BC200603258 (plaintiff’s alternative claim against a party joined by defendant as the solely responsible tortfeasor — Bullock order made). But in either case, the requirement of a sufficient relationship means that something more than the mere objective reasonableness of the joinder of different causes of action is required: Sved v Municipality of Woollahra , above (alternative claims pursued against vendor, builder after suggestion by unsuccessful Council — Bullock order made); Roads and Traffic Authority of NSW v Palmer (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 140; BC200502986 (joinder of RTA not contributed to by Council and contractor defendants — Bullock order refused); Great Lakes Shire Council v Dederer [2006] NSWCA 336; BC200609782 (joinder of Council reasonable, but not established that the conduct of the unsuccessful defendant was such as to make it fair to impose some liability on it for the Council’s costs — Sanderson order refused); Rickard v Allianz Australia Insurance Ltd (No 2) [2010] NSWSC 101; BC201000863 (Sanderson order made).

There has been some debate in the authorities about, and qualified preference for, the desirability of making Sanderson orders, as distinct from Bullock orders, in order to avoid circuitry in the recovery of costs: see Rudow v Great Britain Mutual Life Assurance Society (1881) 17 Ch D 600 ; Sanderson v Blyth Theatre Co [1903] 2 KB 533 at 539 per Romer LJ and at 542–3 per Stirling LJ; Exford Pines Pty Ltd v Vlado’s Pty Ltd (VSC, Ashley J, No 4382/92, 1 April 1996, unreported, BC9601241). In practice, the choice between a Bullock or Sanderson order has little significance where all the parties concerned are solvent and able to pay: Bankamerica Finance Ltd v Nock [1988] AC 1002; [1988] 1 All ER 81 . But where one of the parties is likely to be insolvent, the exercise of the discretion calls for a careful application of the general costs principles (that is, that costs usually follow the event) and an assessment of the fairness (in the particular circumstances) of either making, or refusing to make, a costs order against the party with means: Vucadinovic v Lombardi [1967] VR 81 ; Schipp v Cameron (NSWSC, Einstein J, No 6425/91, 12 October 1998, unreported, BC9806860).

Apart from a discretionary award under CPA s 98 , costs incurred by a party in the conduct of proceedings may sometimes be recoverable as damages: see Hammond & Co v Bussey (1887) 20 QBD 79 at 90 (breach of contract): see McGregor on Damages 16th ed paragraphs [748]–[767].

Where multiple parties share the same legal representation and only some of them succeed at the trial, it is at least a convenient rule of practice to allow the successful parties only an aliquot share of the total costs of the proceedings: Re Colquhoun (1854) 5 De GM & G 35; 43 ER 781; Ellingsen v Det Skandinaviske Compani [1919] 2 KB 567 ; Rogers v Kabriel (No 2) [1999] NSWSC 474; BC9902504 . Indeed, if the costs liability is truly common to all of the represented parties, the compensatory basis of the costs discretion probably requires apportionment: see Bechara v Legal Services Commissioner [2010] NSWCA 369; BC201010442 at [138] and following. Conversely, apportionment is not required if the co-parties bore different responsibility for the costs incurred in the proceedings, or that the issues relied on against the successful co-parties were merely ancillary to the main issues on which the other party succeeded: Korner v H Korner & Co Ltd [1951] Ch 10 .

level.toc-caption: [42.1.52] Costs of parties differently represented in the same proceedings

heading.title: Costs of parties differently represented in the same proceedings

p.text: Ordinarily a party should be represented by the same legal practitioners in respect of any claim or defence in the proceedings. Whilst there is no legal impediment to a party retaining different legal representation in relation to its interests as a plaintiff, on the one hand, and a defendant, on the other, dual representation has an inherent capacity to increase costs, and to do so unnecessarily. Because of that capacity, dual representation requires leave. Leave should not be granted unless the court is satisfied that the interests sought to be separately represented are genuinely conflicting and cannot be adequately pursued by alternative submissions: Van Eeden v Henry (2005) 62 NSWLR 301; 42 MVR 375; [2005] NSWCA 14; BC200500882 (limited costs order where individuals were separately represented as plaintiffs, and as defendants, by their respective insurers — limited costs orders made in favour of successful defendants).

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 42.13–42.15.

Special costs rules apply if proceedings are resolved either by the acceptance of, or following an unsuccessful, offer of compromise: see rr 42.13–42.15 . Where the substance of proceedings is resolved by negotiated settlement but the parties are unable to agree on costs it will rarely be appropriate to determine outstanding costs issues by close investigation of the merits of the respective claims and defences: Australian Securities Commission v Aust-Home Investments Ltd (1993) 44 FCR 194; 116 ALR 523 ; Gribbles Pathology Pty Ltd v Health Insurance Commission (1997) 80 FCR 284; BC9707018 ; Re Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; Ex parte Lai Qin (1997) 186 CLR 622; 143 ALR 1 ; compare Yates Property Corp Pty Ltd v Boland (2000) 179 ALR 664; [2000] FCA 1106; BC200004474 (detailed reasons given in relation to contribution cross-claim applications aborted by the plaintiff's failure on the separate determination of the issue of the defendant's principal liability).

Costs may be awarded against a party where the compromise reflects a substantial capitulation, having regard to the circumstances that prevailed when the circumstances commenced. If the compromise is the material result of changed circumstances, it is generally more appropriate not to make any adverse costs order: Re Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; Ex parte Lai Qin (1997) 186 CLR 622; 143 ALR 1; 71 ALJR 533; BC9700811 . But such an order may be made against a party that has acted unreasonably in the proceedings: Muhibbah Engineering (M) BHD v Trust Co Ltd [2009] NSWCA 205; BC200906586 ; see further [12.1.25] (dealing with discontinuance) and [42.7.10] (dealing with costs of interlocutory proceedings).
Legislation cited in [42.1.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 237, s 242, s 444E.

Costs orders may be made on a winding up summons, notwithstanding, firstly; the provisions of Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) s 444E , and secondly; the provisions of a Deed of Arrangement entered into after the commencement of the proceedings: FAI Workers Compensation (NSW) Ltd v Philkor Builders Pty Ltd (1995) 14 ACLC 323 .

The question of costs of a derivative proceeding or application under Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) s 237 (see [7.1.10] ) is specifically addressed by s 242 of the Act. The court has a very broad discretion to make such orders as it considers just and appropriate for the proper conduct and resolution of the derivative action (including indemnification for costs). Where a derivative action is brought by a minority shareholder to assert the rights of a company, the company will usually be ordered to pay the costs of the shareholder who prosecutes the action on its behalf, if the shareholder is acting in good faith and on reasonable grounds: Wallersteiner v Moir (No 2) [1975] QB 373 at 403 (derivative action on behalf of a company under the general law); Foyster v Foyster Holdings Pty Ltd (2003) 44 ACSR 705; BC200300884 at [13] . If the derivative action is, in substance, a contest between shareholders concerning their personal rights, they may be ordered to bear their own costs of the proceedings: Reale v Duncan Reale Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1099; BC200608467 at [45], [49] (husband and wife shareholders — dispute over matrimonial assets — no order against company).

The court may make an interim order directing that one party bear the costs of prosecuting the proceedings, subject to any further or final order: Access Courier Systems Pty Ltd v Hunsat Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 507; BC200905731 at [3] per Brereton J.
Legislation cited in [42.1.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 s 5.
The court may separately determine the costs on the cross-claim and the costs of the plaintiff proceedings. In so doing, relevant matters for the court to consider include:
the extent to which the cross-claim succeeded;
the likelihood that a cross defendant would, if sued, have been liable to the plaintiff directly and have had to pay costs;
the extent to which a cross defendant participates in the hearing of the plaintiff's claim; and
the extent to which parties to a cross-claim initiated or responded to settlement negotiations: Patten v Moffatt [1999] NSWSC 1322; BC200000309 .

The right to contribution conferred by s 5 of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 extends to contribution to the costs payable to a plaintiff in addition to the damages. That is, the cross-defendant's assessed liability to contribute to the recoverable damages will also determine their contribution to the successful party’s costs: James Hardie & Co Pty Ltd v Wyong Shire Council (2000) 48 NSWLR 679; [2000] NSWCA 107; BC200002083 .

Where the proceedings involve a successful application to stay a criminal prosecution the court may still apply the general rule that in criminal proceedings costs will not be awarded either in favour of or against the Crown: Goia v R (1988) 19 FCR 212; 81 ALR 656 .
Legislation cited in [42.1.75] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 s 99.

The Succession Act 2006 s 99 confers a general discretion to order the costs of succession proceedings be paid from the deceased’s estate. This specific power contemplates a general position where an executor or administrator’s costs of the proceedings will be ordered to be paid from the estate, if they have been reasonably incurred: McCusker v Rutter [2010] NSWCA 318; BC201008879 ; Forsyth v Sinclair (No 2) [2010] VSCA 195; BC201005509 at [23]–[26]; Wang v D’Ambrosio [1999] NSWSC 227; BC9901163 ; Dehnert v Perpetual Executors and Trustees Association of Australia Ltd (1954) 91 CLR 177 at 191–2; [1954] ALR 837; (1954) 28 ALJR 355; BC5400490 . Similarly costs reasonably incurred by a successful claimant, will be ordered to be paid from the estate: Jvancich v Kennedy (No 2) [2004] NSWCA 397; BC200407396 at [13]–[18] (executor’s successful appeal — claimant’s provision reduced).

But the specific power conferred by s 99 of the Succession Act 2006, and many cases, recognises the special nature of succession proceedings. There is an acceptance that the proper exercise of the costs discretion requires a general assessment, including the formal result of the proceedings: Jvancich v Kennedy (No 2) [2004] NSWCA 397; BC200407396 at [11] per Giles JA. This requirement to take into account other considerations than the mere formal “event” in the proceedings has been described as “the overall justice of the case”: Singer v Berghouse (1993) 114 ALR 521 at 522; (1993) 67 ALJR 708; BC9303604 .

This impressionistic consideration certainly permits regard to the formal result of the proceedings. Consequently an unsuccessful claimant will ordinarily be ordered to pay the estate’s costs of the proceedings: McCusker v Rutter [2010] NSWCA 318; BC201008879 ; Carey v Robson (No 2) [2009] NSWSC 1199; BC200910083 at [7], [19]–[21]; Moussa v Moussa [2006] NSWSC 509; BC200603748 ; Bowditch v NSW Trustee and Guardian [2012] NSWSC 702; BC201204623 . That ordinary position will likely apply if the estate is small: Dobb v Hacket (1993) 10 WAR 532 at 540. It is very likely to apply if the failed claim lacked reasonable prospects of success, or was otherwise conducted improperly or unreasonably pursued: Re Sitch (No 2) [2005] VSC 383; BC200507079 ; Harkness v Harkness (No 2) [2012] NSWSC 35; BC201203038 at [18] and following per Hallen AsJ.

But the general position may be departed from, where a claim failed but was reasonable and meritorious. In such a case, if the claimant’s financial position would be significantly adversely affected by having to meet any costs liability, it may be appropriate to make no adverse costs order: Re Sherborne Estate (No 2); Vanvalen v Neaves (2005) 65 NSWLR 268; [2005] NSWSC 1003; BC200507645 at [61]–[66] per Palmer J; Singer v Berghouse (1993) 114 ALR 521 at 522; (1993) 67 ALJR 708; BC9303604 ; Reddie v Cornock [2005] NSWSC 187; BC200501398 ; Mikan v Velcich (No 2) [2011] NSWSC 505; BC201103778 at [23]–[25]. It is particularly likely to be an appropriate order if a material reason for the claimant’s failure was their financial circumstances, and they would be materially adversely affected by the potential costs liability: Re McDougall v Rogers; estate of James Rogers [2006] NSWSC 484; BC200603648 . Apart from these situations, it may sometimes be appropriate to award the costs of an unsuccessful, but substantially meritorious, claimant be paid from the estate: Re Bodman [1972] Qd R 281 ; Mikan v Velcich (No 2) [2011] NSWSC 505; BC201103778 at [16](i): but see Nicholls v Hall [2007] NSWCA 356; BC200710898 at [57].

See also Practice Note SC Eq 7 — Family Provision para 24. Orders may be made capping the amount of costs that may be recovered by a party. The circumstances in which such an order may be made include, but are not limited to, proceedings where the estate value is less than $500,000.

level.toc-caption: [42.1.78] Children and Young Persons (Care and Protection) Act 1998

heading.title: Children and Young Persons (Care and Protection) Act 1998

p.text: There is no special immunity from costs in proceedings within the Supreme Court’s protective jurisdiction, even where the subject matter of the proceedings is also within the scope of the Children and Young Persons (Care and Protection) Act 1998. The “exceptional circumstance” requirement that applies under s 88 of the Children and Young Persons (Care and Protection) Act 1998) before costs orders can be made un proceedings under the Act, does not apply to proceedings in the Supreme Court: Wilson v Dept of Human Services; Re Anna (No 2) [2011] NSWSC 545; BC201104826 at [80] and [106] endorsed in Re Kerry (No 2) — Costs [2012] NSWCA 194; BC201206151 .
Legislation cited in [42.1.80] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.25.

This rule also applies if the defendant is a fiduciary. If the fiduciary, as an executor, receiver, liquidator or trustee and the proceedings directly relate to the administration of the property they hold in that capacity, they will generally be entitled to an indemnity from that property, unless they have acted unreasonably in the defence of the proceedings: Hypec Electronics Pty Ltd (in liq) v Mead (2004) 50 ACSR 448; [2004] NSWSC 731; BC200405114 (liquidator — indemnity refused); Re Buena Vista Motors Pty Ltd (in liq) [1971] 1 NSWLR 72 (liquidator — indemnity allowed); Miller v Cameron (1936) 54 CLR 572 at 578–9 (trustee opposing application for removal — indemnity refused); Expo International Pty Ltd (in liq) v Chant (No 2) (1980) 5 ACLR 193 at 197–8 (liquidator — indemnity allowed); Lewis v Nortex Pty Ltd (in liq) [2006] NSWSC 480; BC200603586 (liquidator — indemnity allowed) . See further r 42.25 and the accompanying notes.

The same principles apply to the exercise of the costs discretion whether or not one of the parties is a legally assisted person. Under s 42 of the Legal Aid Commission Act 1979, a court must make the same costs order as would be appropriate if the person entitled, or bound, was not legally assisted.

The basic rule that costs follow the event applies to contested probate proceedings: Bar-Mordecai v Rotman (NSWSC, Einstein J, No 120009/94, 4 September 1998, unreported, BC9804681). But it is subject to three qualifications:

An executor who properly moves to propound a will, will ordinarily be entitled to an indemnity from the estate, even if the proceedings are not successful: Re Estate of the late Hazel Ruby Grounds; Page v Sedawie [2005] NSWSC 1311; BC200511129 at [35]; Shorter v Hodges (1988) 14 NSWLR 698 at 709G.

Where the proceedings are attributable to the conduct of the testator, or those interested in residue of the estate: Re Cutcliffe’s Estate [1959] P 6 . In the application of this qualification costs may be ordered to be paid out of the estate where an unsuccessful challenge to the grant of probate was attributable to the conduct of the deceased: In the estate of Moyle: Moyle v Moyle (NSWSC) , Santow J, 9 April 1998, unreported, BC9801221); Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd v Baker [1999] NSWCA 244; BC9904032 (probate grantee unsuccessful respondent on appeal — costs paid from estate).

Where the circumstances reasonably required investigation of the document propounded for probate: Shorter v Hodges (1988) 14 NSWLR 698 at 709 per Powell J. In the application of the second exception, the respective parties may be left to bear their own costs of the proceedings: Shorten v Shorten (No 2) [2003] NSWCA 60; BC200301829 ; Shorter v Hodges, above; Middlebrook v Middlebrook (1962) 36 ALJR 216 (reasonable but unsuccessful challenge to testators capacity); Szabo v Battye (No 2) [2006] NSWSC 1392; BC200610516 (justifiable challenge to testamentary capacity).

The qualifications, particularly the second and third, are conceptually distinct, but have a capacity to overlap — because of the extent to which “confusion” in the deceased’s affairs, or doubts about the rationality of their conduct, may be ascribed to relevant “fault”: Shorten v Shorten (No 2) [2003] NSWCA 60; BC200301829 at [19]; Dawson v Peters (No 2) [2007] NSWSC 1421; BC200710721 at [8].

Where proceedings involve the conduct of public authorities in the discharge of their powers and obligations, that circumstance may provide a basis for declining to order that costs follow the event. Where the unsuccessful party is, or includes, ordinary litigants who have acted responsibly in their conduct of the proceedings, the fact that the issues concern matters of public importance may provide a basis for orders that each party bear their own costs of the proceedings: Lyster v Camberwell City Council (1989) 69 LGRA 250 (proceedings brought by the Minister for Local Government against the council); Kent v Cavanagh (1973) 1 ACTR 43 (private citizens action against the minister); Independent Commission Against Corruption v Cripps (NSWSC, Sully J, 27 August 1986, unreported) (a party before the commission was not ordered to pay the costs of ICAC, which successfully opposed the party’s claim for legal professional privilege in relation to certain documents); Minister for Planning v Walker (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 334; BC200810814 (each party ordered to pay own costs —– characterisation as public interest litigation only one factor in displacing the ordinary rule of costs —– insufficient on its own). However, an order for the payment of costs is principally a matter of compensation to the successful party. Accordingly, the circumstances in which public interest considerations can properly be regarded as significantly influencing the costs discretion must be regarded as special. As a general proposition, neither the fact that the unsuccessful party had an arguable case, nor that it participated in the litigation as a matter of public interest, is an important consideration in the exercise of the discretion to award costs: Latoudis v Casey (1990) 170 CLR 534; 97 ALR 45 ; — Hastings Point Progress Association Inc v Tweed Shire Council (No 3) (2010) 172 LGERA 157; [2010] NSWCA 39; BC201001448 . But the importance of the consideration will depend upon the relevant statutory provisions and the particular circumstances. The existence of an “open standing” legislative provision, as well as the nature and significance of the matters in issue, may justify special orders in relation to costs, notwithstanding the actual outcome of the litigation: Oshlack v Richmond River Council (1998) 193 CLR 72 at 94–95; 152 ALR 83 ; North Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service Inc v Bradley (No 2) [2002] FCA 564; BC200202158 (reduction in proportion of costs awarded against a “public interest” litigant who resisted challenges to its standing but was otherwise unsuccessful).

The court has an inherent discretion to allow set-off of costs orders in the same proceedings: Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWCA, Priestley and Clarke JJA & Grove AJA, 21 February 1996, unreported, BC9600213); Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWSC, Young J, No 3748/89, 12 December 1994, unreported, BC9403409). Historically the power was regarded as an incident of the court’s procedural powers: Edwards v Hope (1885) 14 QBD 922 at 926 ; Reid v Cupper [1915] 2 KB 147 at 149, 151 . The court also has a discretion to allow a set-off of any judgments in any (including different) proceedings in the court and independently of any statutory right of set-off: Mitchell v Oldfield (1791) 4 TR 123; 100 ER 929. The discretionary power even extends to the grant of a stay of execution of an order for costs in order to facilitate the utility of the set-off: Re a Debtor [1951] Ch 612 (enforcement of costs in bankruptcy proceedings stayed on the application of the judgment creditor).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.2] r 42.2 General rule as to assessment of costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 32; DCR Part 39A, rule 10; LCR Part 31A, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: General rule as to assessment of costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 32; DCR Part 39A, rule 10; LCR Part 31A, rule 6)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise or these rules otherwise provide, costs payable to a person under an order of the court or these rules are to be assessed on the ordinary basis.
Legislation cited in [42.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 98(4).

Historically rules of court provided for the assessment of taxation of costs on several different basis: see generally Hurstville Municipal Council v Connor (1991) 24 NSWLR 724 at 731 . The present rules specifically refer to costs being payable on the ordinary basis; see [42.2.20] ; and on an indemnity basis: see [42.5.5] . However both the terms of the present rule, and the width of the power conferred by CPA s 98(4) suggest that the court may order the payment of costs on some other basis. In that context it is common to refer to “solicitor/client” costs in contra-distinction to “party/party” costs. Taxation on the former basis was previously provided for in some rules of court. Orders for costs to be taxed between parties on “a solicitor and client basis” have been made: Baltic Shipping Co v Dillon (The Mikhail Lermontov) (1991) 22 NSWLR 1; ASC ¶56-039 . As defined in previous rules, costs payable on a solicitor client basis included costs that would otherwise be regarded as unreasonable, if they were approved by the client. So expressed, this basis of assessment is more generous than that contemplated for indemnity costs under r 42.5; and clearly there is potential for a considerable difference between costs on a party and party basis and costs on a solicitor and client basis: Qantas Airways Ltd v Dillingham Corp (NSWSC, Rogers J, 14 May 1987, No 16537/84, unreported, BC8701371); Stanley v Phillips (1966) 115 CLR 470 at 478, 489; [1967] ALR 197 . The difficulties of applying the “solicitor/client” basis are discussed by Saddington, “Costs as Between Solicitor and Client” (1947) 20 ALJ 423.

The basic principle is that costs are awarded by way of indemnity to a successful party for costs incurred in the successful conduct of the proceedings: Gundry v Sainsbury [1910] 1 KB 645 at 649 ; Harold v Smith (1860) 157 ER 1229 at 1231 ; Irving v Gagliardi; Ex parte Gagliardi (No 2) (1895) 6 QLJ 200 .

If the costs have actually been paid they will be recoverable: TNT Bulkships Ltd v Hopkins (1989) 65 NTR 1; 98 FLR 352 ; Elders Trustee & Executor Co Ltd; Estate of Howard v Estate of Herbert (1996) 5 NTLR 123; 111 NTR 25 at 33; 132 FLR 24; BC9601883 . This includes situations where the party’s liability has been met by a third person’s payment (and that third person has an enforceable right or repayment): Coshott v Woollahra Council [2008] NSWCA 176; BC200806951 ; Coates v Harbour Radio Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 796; BC201005082 .

If the costs have not been paid they are only recoverable to the extent the party has an actual liability to pay them: Wentworth v Rogers (2006) 66 NSWLR 474; [2006] NSWCA 145; BC200604064 at [45]. This liability may be contingent on the party’s success on the substantive issues in the proceedings, but it is not clear, and differing views have been expressed, whether the potential liability is sufficient where it is expressed to be contingent on obtaining a favourable costs order in the proceedings: Wentworth v Rogers (2006) 66 NSWLR 474; [2006] NSWCA 145; BC200604064 at [50]–[51] per Santow JA and [161]–[167] per Basten JA.

The potential costs liability must involve an enforceable cause of action relating to the agreement to pay costs: TNT Bulkships Ltd v Hopkins (1989) 65 NTR 1; 98 FLR 352 (unpaid costs claimed by a solicitor who has no practising certificate are not recoverable); Re Sweeting [1898] 1 Ch 268; (1898) 67 LJ Ch 159; 78 LT 6; 14 TLR 171 ; Browne v Barber [1913] 2 KB 553 ; contrast Elders Trustee & Executor Co Ltd; Estate of Howard v Estate of Herbert (1996) 5 NTLR 123; 111 NTR 25 at 33; 132 FLR 24; BC9601883 (costs recoverable where interstate solicitor engages local agent). Consequently, costs are not recoverable to the extent that they are limited by the claimant's status: Carson v Pickersgill & Sons (1885) 14 QBD 859 (plaintiff in an action in forma pauperis), or by agreement: Tarry v Pryce (No 2) (1987) 88 FLR 270 .

The indemnity principle does not preclude an award of costs in favour of a person whose status as party in the proceedings is merely formal or nominal: R v Archbishop of Canterbury [1903] 1 KB 289 (public servant); Dyktynski v BHP Titanium Minerals Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 154; BC200402706 ; Lenthall v Hillson [1933] SASR 31 (police officer complainant); Blackall v Trotter (No 1) [1969] VR 939 at 947 (Crown solicitor acting for a party); McCullum v Ifield [1969] 2 NSWR 329 (defendant indemnified by insurer). Neither does it prevent an order for costs being made if the successful party has an actual legal liability to their solicitors even if they are in fact unlikely to be called on to discharge it personally: Adams v London Improved Motor Coach Builders Ltd [1921] 1 KB 495; [1920] All ER Rep 340 (solicitors acting for an individual plaintiff on instructions from the plaintiff's trade union); Backhouse v Judd [1925] SASR 395 (solicitor retained by an officer of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals).

In the application of the indemnity principle, a distinction needs to be drawn between legal liability in the strict sense and the question whether the solicitors can in fact recover the full amount of the costs charged. Thus, the fact that the successful party is a company in liquidation does not disentitle it to an order for costs: Angor Pty Ltd v Ilich Motor Co Pty Ltd (1992) 37 FCR 65 .

Issues relating to the application of the indemnity principle should ordinarily be determined in the assessment process, rather than in connection with the making of an initial order for the payment of costs: Graham v Aluma-Lite Pty Ltd [1996] NSWCA 227; BC9607803 ; but see Wentworth v Rogers (2006) 66 NSWLR 474; [2006] NSWCA 145; BC200604064 at [48] and [169]–[172].

The costs of work undertaken by an employed lawyer is treated in the usual way by awarding costs on a basis comparable to the costs that would have been allowed if an independent solicitor had been engaged: Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Hattersley (2001) 51 NSWLR 333; [2001] NSWSC 60; BC200100604 ; Attorney-General v Shillibeer (1849) 4 Exch 606 ; Re Eastwood (dec’d); Lloyds Bank Ltd v Eastwood [1974] 3 All ER 603 .

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.2.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: Ordinary basis for assessment of costs

p.text: Under Legal Profession Act 2004 Pt 11 , in particular ss 364 and 365, costs ordered between parties (“party/party costs”) are those which are assessed as fair and reasonable having regard to all the relevant circumstances. The settled practice of the courts has been to order costs on a party and party basis. Although differing views have been expressed on the appropriateness of the party and party basis in ordinary cases (see, for example, Berry v British Transport Commission [1962] 1 QB 306 ; Cachia v Hanes (1991) 23 NSWLR 304 at 318 ; Qantas Airways Ltd v Dillingham Corp (NSWSC, Rogers J, No 16537/84, 14 May 1987, unreported, BC8701371) and although there is a discretion to award costs on other bases, the court ought generally to confine costs orders to assessment on the ordinary basis unless the particular circumstances of the case require that a different order be made: Colgate-Palmolive Co v Cussons Pty Ltd (1993) 46 FCR 225 at 233; 118 ALR 248 .

heading.title: Litigant in person — costs ordered in favour of

p.text: A litigant in person may recover costs for reasonably incurred disbursements and witness expenses Secretary, Department of Foreign Affairs v Boswell (1992) 39 FCR 288; 111 ALR 553; BC9203911 ; Deva v University of Western Sydney (2008) EOC ¶93-497; 175 IR 89; [2008] NSWCA 137; BC200804540 at [82] (filing fees). These include:

court fees, filing fees and transcript costs: B v P [2000] FamCA 392 at [50] ; W (deceased) v W [2004] FamCA 319 at [41]; Secretary, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade v Boswell (1992) 39 FCR 288; 111 ALR 553; BC9203911 ; Deva v University of Western Sydney (2008) EOC ¶93-497; 175 IR 89; [2008] NSWCA 137; BC200804540 at [82] (filing fees);
expenses for serving documents: Winter v Fleeton [2002] WASCA 73; BC200201807 at [23] ;
fees incurred in searching public registers: Re Sullivan and Department of Industry, Science and Technology (1998) 51 ALD 767 at [45] ;

incidental expenses in relation to photocopying, postage and telephone and facsimile transmissions: Shephard v Blueberry Farms of Australia (Corindi) Ltd (2001) 162 FLR 339; [2001] FMCA 2 at [66] ; Cary v Owners of Strata Plan No 7241 [2002] FMCA 18; BC200200379 ;

costs and disbursements for legal work done by others: London Scottish Benefit Society v Chorley [1881-5] All ER Rep 1111; (1884) 13 QBD 872 ; Malkinson v Trim [2002] All ER (D) 66 (Sep); [2003] 2 All ER 356; [2003] 1 WLR 463; [2002] EWCA Civ 1273 ;

ordinary fees, or expenses, for their own time as a witness in the proceedings: Cachia v Hanes (1994) 179 CLR 403 at 417; 120 ALR 385; 68 ALJR 374; BC9404608 ; Lawrence v MD Nikolaidis & Co (2003) 57 NSWLR 355; [2003] NSWCA 129; BC200303669 at [37] .
Expenses which have been held NOT to be recoverable include:

travelling expenses: W (deceased) v W [2004] FamCA 319 at [49]; Farquar and Farquar (No 2) [2008] FamCA 682; BC200850533 ; Cachia v Hanes (1994) 179 CLR 403 at 417; 120 ALR 385; 68 ALJR 374; BC9404608 ;
parking costs: H v H [2006] FamCA 167 at [9];
meals: Maronis Holdings Ltd v Nippon Credit Australia Ltd [2002] NSWSC 838; BC200207616 at [14];
loss of earnings incurred by the litigant in presenting and conducting a case: Cachia v Hanes (1994) 179 CLR 403 at 417; 120 ALR 385; 68 ALJR 374; BC9404608 .

A litigant in person is not entitled to costs for their own time in the preparation and conduct of the proceedings: Cachia v Hanes (1991) 23 NSWLR 304 ; Cachia v Hanes (1994) 179 CLR 403; 120 ALR 385; 68 ALJR 374; BC9404608 ; Lawrence v MD Nikolaidis & Co (2003) 57 NSWLR 355; [2003] NSWCA 129; BC200303669 at [37] ; Preston v Cmr for Fair Trading (2011) 80 NSWLR 359; [2011] NSWCA 40; BC201102297 at [182]–[185] (determining that this limitation applied under CPA s 98(1) .

If the successful litigant in person is a lawyer there is authority for the view that they can claim to be remunerated for ordinary professional services they performed: London Scottish Benefit Society v Chorley [1881-5] All ER Rep 1111; (1884) 13 QBD 872 ; Guss v Veenhuizen (No 2) (1976) 136 CLR 47; 12 ALR 271; 51 ALJR 209; BC7600103 ; Lawrence v MD Nikolaidis & Co (2003) 57 NSWLR 355; [2003] NSWCA 129; BC200303669 except in so far as they are either unnecessary or impossible, for instance, in relation to consultations with himself: Buckland v Watts [1970] 1 QB 27; [1969] 2 All ER 985; [1969] 3 WLR 92 ; cf H Tolputt & Company Ltd v Mole [1911] 1 KB 87 . This potential entitlement of a lawyer litigant in person requires a distinction to be made between their activities as a lawyer and as a personal litigant. It was described in Cachia v Hanes (1994) 179 CLR 403 at 411–2; 120 ALR 385; 68 ALJR 374; BC9404608 ; as a “limited and questionable exception” to the general rule. In Dobree v Hoffman (1996) 18 WAR 36; BC9606034 , the Supreme Court (WA) refused to apply Chorley and held that a solicitor was not entitled to recover profit costs in respect of professional work done as a litigant in person. In Atlas Corp Pty Ltd v Kalyk [2001] NSWCA 10; BC200100339 the NSW Court of Appeal held that Guss v Veenhuizen, above, obliged the court to follow the Chorley rule despite the decision in Dobree, above. Khera v Jones [2006] NSWCA 85; BC200602698 (unemployed solicitor representing himself) cast “further doubt on the sustainability of the Chorley rule” at [3], and the Court of Appeal further said “were the matter uncluttered by authority we would favour the approach in Dobree … but there is little reason to think that this court would depart from its firm and comparatively recent decision in Atlas ”. In relation to indemnity costs and litigants in person see “Cachia v Hanes : The Resurgence of the Indemnity Principle in Australia” (1995) 13 Aust Bar Review 177.

The costs of a party who enters a submitting appearance will generally be adequately provided for by a conventional costs order providing for taxation on the ordinary basis: Cook v ANZ Bank (NSWSC, McLelland CJ in Eq, 16 June 1995, BC9504784) –– distinguishing the Practice Note (1956) 30 ALJ 87 (which outlined the principle applicable to the incidence of the costs of disinterested trustees in litigation involving a trust estate).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.4] r 42.4 Power to order maximum costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 35A)

leg:heading.title: Power to order maximum costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 35A)

p.text: The court may by order, of its own motion or on the application of a party, specify the maximum costs that may be recovered by one party from another.
A maximum amount specified in an order under subrule (1) may not include an amount that a party is ordered to pay because the party:
has failed to comply with an order or with any of these rules, or
has sought leave to amend its pleadings or particulars, or
has sought an extension of time for complying with an order or with any of these rules, or
has otherwise caused another party to incur costs that were not necessary for the just, quick and cheap:
progress of the proceedings to trial or hearing, or
trial or hearing of the proceedings.
An order under subrule (1) may include such directions as the court considers necessary to effect the just, quick and cheap:
progress of the proceedings to trial or hearing, or
trial or hearing of the proceedings.
If, in the court’s opinion, there are special reasons, and it is in the interests of justice to do so, the court may vary the specification of maximum recoverable costs ordered under subrule (1).

level.toc-caption: [42.4.5] Limiting the amount of recoverable costs

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 56(4), s 60, and 98, s 99.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.3, r 42.4(1), (3) and (4).

heading.title: Limiting the amount of recoverable costs

p.text: The powers conferred by the present rule complement the obligation imposed by CPA s 60 . Section 60 requires the court's practice and procedure to be applied with a view to achieving proportionality between the cost of the proceedings and their importance and complexity. The combined effect of the two provision is to endorse proportionality as central to the just and efficient conduct of civil proceedings: Lownds v Home Office [2002] 4 All ER 775. The present rule permits the court to make orders that limit the costs that may be recovered following the determination of the proceedings: see Nudd v Mannix [2009] NSWCA 327; BC200909764 (family provisions matter — trial judge had power to make an order capping the plaintiff’s costs of the trial at $60,000); Delta Electricity v Blue Mountains Conservation Society Inc (2010) 176 LGERA 424; [2010] NSWCA 263; BC2010007625 (contravention of Protection of the Environment Operations Act 1997 — on appeal, costs capping order by LEC upheld – maximum costs of $20,000 — public interest litigation).

As r 42.4(1), (3) and (4) implicitly contemplate, the intended effect of achieving proportionality will be best served where orders limiting costs are made prospectively and early in the course of the proceedings. It is undesirable (except for the purpose of making an appropriate variation of an earlier order) to exercise the power retrospectively: Re Sherborne Estate (No 2); Vanvalen v Neaves [2005] NSWSC 1003; BC200507645 at [22]–[26] and [31]

If costs have been unnecessarily incurred or increased by the conduct of either of the parties, or their legal representatives, the court may take that matter into account, either in the exercise of its general discretion as to costs: see CPA ss 56(4) and 98 ; or its powers under CPA s 99 and UCPR r 42.3 . The principles relevant to the exercise of the court's general powers to make proportionate, and gross sum, costs orders are discussed in notes [s 98.45] –[s 98.63].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.5] r 42.5 Indemnity costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 37)

p.text: If the court determines that costs are to be paid on an indemnity basis:
in the case of costs payable out of property held or controlled by a person who is a party to the proceedings:
in the capacity of trustee, executor, administrator or legal representative of a deceased estate, or
in any other fiduciary capacity,
all costs (other than those that have been incurred in breach of the person’s duty in that capacity) are to be allowed, and
in any other case, all costs (other than those that appear to have been unreasonably incurred or appear to be of an unreasonable amount) are to be allowed.
Legislation cited in [42.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.1, rr 42.14, 42.15, r 42.25, r 42.5(a).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 98.

The ordinary rule is that costs follow the event: see r 42.1 . However, costs may be ordered on an indemnity basis under CPA s 98 and, perhaps, under the court's incidental power to control their proceedings: see Walton v McBride (1995) 36 NSWLR 440 at 461 per Powell JA. An award of indemnity costs pre-supposes either a party’s special entitlement (arising, for example, from the control or possession of property: see r 42.5(a) and r 42.25 ) or some relevant unreasonable action, including relevant misconduct, in connection with the conduct of the proceedings, by the person against whom the order is made: Oshlack v Richmond River Council (1998) 193 CLR 72; 152 ALR 83; [1998] HCA 11; BC9800310 ; Harrison v Schipp [2001] NSWCA 13; BC200100344 ; NMFM Property Pty Ltd v Citibank Ltd (No 11) (2001) 109 FCR 77; 187 ALR 654; [2001] FCA 480; BC200101932 . The qualification that the hypothesised action must relate to the conduct of the proceedings distinguishes the award of indemnity costs from aggravated and exemplary damages — which relate to the circumstances and consequences of the conduct that gave rise to the proceedings. A party may suffer both an award of aggravated damages and an order for indemnity costs in the same proceedings: Vignoli v Sydney Harbour Casino (No 2) [1999] NSWSC 1227; BC9908228 . Consistent with the general principle that requires relevant misconduct before an indemnity costs order is made, the exercise of the discretion to award costs on an indemnity basis may be influenced by the existence and content of any prior notice the applicant has given of the intention to make the claim: Huntsman Chemical Co Australia Ltd v International Pools Australia Pty Ltd (1995) 36 NSWLR 242; 125 FLR 151; BC9504308 (see in particular ground (b) in the examples below). But the circumstances in which an order for indemnity costs may be made include situations where prior notice is neither necessary nor realistically to be expected (see examples (a), (g) and (h) below). Consequently, the absence of prior notice will not necessarily preclude such an order being made: Horseshoe Pastoral Co Pty Ltd v Murray Smith (NSWCA, Kirby P, Clarke and Powell JJA, No 440026/93, 7 November 1995, unreported, BC9501903).
The situations in which orders for indemnity costs have been ordered include the following examples where:
a party has misled the court: Wentworth v Rogers [1999] NSWCA 403; BC9907174 at [81] ;

a party has maintained proceedings that they should have known had no real prospect of success: Fountain Selected Meats (Sales) Pty Ltd v International Produce Merchants Pty Ltd (1988) 81 ALR 397 at 401 (citing examples of fraud allegations known to be either untrue or irrelevant); Re Bond Corp Holdings Ltd (1990) 1 WAR 465; 1 ACSR 350; 8 ACLC 153 ; Colgate-Palmolive Co v Cussons Pty Ltd (1993) 46 FCR 225 at 233–4; 118 ALR 248; 28 IPR 561; BC9305213 (citing examples of groundless allegations); Rosniak v GIO (NSW) (1997) 41 NSWLR 608; 26 MVR 204; (1997) Aust Torts Reports 81-440; BC9702453 ; Varga Group Investments (No 8) Pty Ltd v Geebung Investments Pty Ltd (SC(NSW), Abadee J, 15 November 1994, unreported, BC9403509); Baillieu Knight Frank (NSW) Pty Ltd v Ted Manny Real Estate Pty Ltd (1992) 30 NSWLR 359; 10 ACSR 537 (winding up pro-ceedings instituted on the basis of a debt known to be disputed indemnity costs); Chaina v Alvaro Homes Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 353; BC200811259 at [111]–[113] (lack of objective evidence to support claim); Ng v Chong [2010] NSWSC 127; BC201001037 at [19], [20] (appeal proceedings commenced and maintained in wilful disregard of known facts); Sewell v Zelden (No 2) [2010] NSWSC 1181; BC201007793 at [53] (no realistic prospect of success in resisting claim for breach of fiduciary duty);

a party has abandoned claims: Ianelli v Hancock t/as Hancocks Solicitors [2012] NSWSC 417; BC201207218 ; Lahoud v Lahoud [2006] NSWSC 126; BC200601167 at [44]–[69] (untenable claim) However such a situation has to be distinguished from a belated acceptance of the unlikelihood of success: Huntsman Chemical Co Australia Ltd v International Pools Australia Pty Ltd (1995) 36 NSWLR 242 at 247; 125 FLR 151; (1995) ATPR 41-403; BC9504308 . Similarly, the abandonment of claims for the purpose of narrowing the real issues in dispute and reducing the cost and complexity of the proceedings will not justify an order for indemnity costs: Lahoud v Lahoud [2006] NSWSC 126; BC200601167 at [23]–[43];
proceedings were maintained for an ulterior purpose: Cultus Petroleum v OMV Australia [1999] NSWSC 435; BC9902283 ;
the conduct of proceedings has caused unreasonable delay and expense: Wentworth v Rogers [1999] NSWCA 403; BC9907174 at [85] ;
a defendant unreasonably delayed an admission of liability for the purpose of obtaining a tactical advantage: Rouse v Shepherd (No 2) (1994) 35 NSWLR 277 ;
an order has been made against a person declared to be a vexatious litigant: Valassis v MD Nikolaidis & Co [2000] NSWSC 388; BC200002393 ;
an order has been made against a person or party in contempt: EMI Records v Ian Cameron Wallace Pty Ltd [1983] Ch 59 ; Degnam Pty Ltd (in liq) v Wright (No 2) [1983] 2 NSWLR 354 at 358 ;

a party obtained a judgment no better than a prior settlement offer by the other party: Multicon Engineering Pty Ltd v Federal Airports Corp (1996) 138 ALR 425 ; Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd v CE Heath Underwriting & Agency Services (1995) 8 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61-231; (1994) 12 BCL 415 per Hunter J; see rr 42.14 and 42.15 .

In adoption proceedings it may be appropriate to award costs against the relevant department where it unsuccessfully opposed the adoption on policy grounds that had occasioned additional costs: Re H and Adoption Act (2004) 62 NSWLR 245; 32 Fam LR 662; [2004] NSWSC 1242; BC200408743 at [23] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.6] r 42.6 Amendment of pleading etc without leave (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Amendment of pleading etc without leave (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 15)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, a party that amends a pleading or summons without leave must, after the conclusion of the proceedings, pay the costs of and occasioned by the amendment.

The phrase ‘occasioned by’ requires consideration of causal consequences: eg Gunns Forest Products Pty Ltd v North Insurances Pty Ltd [2004] VSC 155; BC200402813 at [19] (in the context of an insurance policy). In the context of an amendment, the costs that are “of and ‘occasioned by’” any amendment, will involve consideration by the assessor of actual circumstances of each case. At one end of the range the costs may be simply limited to work done in considering the proposed amendment and drafting any responsive documents to deal with it (such as an amended defence to an amended statement of claim). At the other end of the range there will be situations such as that which arose in SH Lock & Co (A/asia) Ltd v Rudders Ltd (1932) 49 WN (NSW) 65 . The plaintiff sued the defendant for fraudulent misrepresentation. At the hearing the plaintiff obtained leave to amend the declaration by omitting allegations of fraud and knowledge. The defendant then obtained leave to plead payment into court of the amount claimed and was allowed the “costs of the amendment”. The taxing officer allowed the defendant all costs that had been wasted or expenses that had been rendered nugatory by the action of the plaintiff in framing his action in fraud, and allowed the plaintiff only such costs as it would have been allowed if it had originally declared on a cause of action excluding fraud and on such cause of action the defendant immediately paid the money into court. Halse Rogers J dismissed a summons to review the taxation.
Legislation cited in [42.6.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

This rule does not apply to the following classes of proceedings in the Land and Environment Court: Class 1 (environmental planning and protection appeals), Class 2 (local government and miscellaneous appeals and applications) and Class 3 (land tenure, valuation, ratings and compensation matters).
