leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.7] r 42.7 Interlocutory applications and reserved costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 16; DCR Part 39A, rule 22; LCR Part 31A, rule 17)

leg:heading.title: Interlocutory applications and reserved costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 16; DCR Part 39A, rule 22; LCR Part 31A, rule 17)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, the costs of any application or other step in any proceedings, including:
costs that are reserved, and
costs in respect of any such application or step in respect of which no order as to costs is made,
are to be paid and otherwise dealt with in the same way as the general costs of the proceedings.
Unless the court orders otherwise, costs referred to in subrule (1) do not become payable until the conclusion of the proceedings.

The costs of an interlocutory application, the order includes both the costs of, and incidental to, the application (that is, both the costs of preparing for, and those of attending, court on the relevant hearing): Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWCA, Priestley, Clarke JJA and Grove AJA, 40374/95, 21 February 1996, unreported, BC9600215) at 17 per Clarke JJA.

Courts commonly order that the costs of an interlocutory application are “costs in the cause” –– or “the plaintiff’s/defendant's costs in the cause”. Such an order does not involve fettering of the discretion of the court provided the rule is applied in the exercise of the discretion and not as a matter of course: Petar v Macedonian Orthodox Community Church St Petka Inc (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 142; BC200704622 at [18]–[28] . The distinction between the two orders is as follows:

costs in the cause — the successful party at the final hearing will also be entitled to their costs of the interlocutory proceedings: JT Stratford & Son Ltd v Lindley (No 2) [1969] 3 All ER 1122; [1969] 1 WLR 1547 at 1552–3 ;

plaintiff’s/defendant’s costs in the cause — the unsuccessful party in the interlocutory proceedings cannot recover their costs of the application even if they ultimately succeed at the final hearing of the proceedings. See Petar v The Macedonian Orthodox Community Church St Petka Inc (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 142; BC200704622 at [18]–[23] .

level.toc-caption: [42.7.10] Costs of interlocutory applications disposed of by consent

heading.title: Costs of interlocutory applications disposed of by consent

p.text: There is a public interest in encouraging parties to compromise interlocutory applications without risking the penalty of an adverse costs order. For that reason, it is sometimes said that the court should be reluctant to order costs where the compromise of an interlocutory application does not include agreement on costs: Gambro Pty Ltd v Fresenius Medical Care Australia Pty Ltd [2002] FCA 581; BC200202312 . However, this is at best a very general consideration, and a "compromise" which represents a substantial capitulation, rather than constructive co-operation in the efficient resolution of the proceedings, may readily justify a costs order in favour of the successful party: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2003] NSWSC 297; BC200301645 .
Legislation cited in [42.7.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.6, r 42.7(1)(a).

The effect of reserving the costs of interlocutory proceedings is to make them recoverable as the costs of the successful party in the proceedings, unless some contrary order is made by the court: see UCPR r 42.7(1)(a) ; O’Keefe Nominees Pty Ltd v BP Australia Limited (No 2) (1995) 55 FCR 591 at 598 ; Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2006] NSWSC 895; BC200607058 ; Woods v Walsh (1989) 22 FCR 204 . It will be appropriate to make a contrary order where the interlocutory application was collateral to the main proceedings: Mummery v Campbell (1834) 10 Bing 511; 131 ER 993; Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWCA, Clarke JA, 21 February 1996, unreported, BC9600215). But the court’s discretion to make a contrary order is not limited to such a situation and the court retains its general discretion, including its power either to deprive a successful party of their costs or to order costs against such a party. Orders of the latter kind may in fact be made almost as a matter of course in some instances, such as those involving a successful application for leave to amend; see UCPR r 42.6 .
Legislation cited in [42.7.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 98.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 36.10, rr 36.4, r 42.7(2), r 7(2).

The costs power in CPA s 98 permits the court to make costs orders at any stage of the proceedings. But for the limitation contained in r 42.7(2) , such an order would take effect either when it was made or when a cost assessor’s certificate was filed and the favoured party would be entitled to judgment accordingly: see UCPR rr 36.4 and 36.10 . This restriction also applies to the costs of an appeal from the interlocutory decision: Petar v The Macedonian Orthodox Community Church St Petka Inc (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 142; BC200704622 at [49] . The power in UCPR r 7(2) to order otherwise does not have to be exercised by the judge who made the original court order, nor does the “otherwise order” have to be made at the same time as the original order for costs: Showtime Touring Group Pty Ltd v Mosley Touring Inc (2013) 296 ALR 597; [2013] NSWCA 53; BC201301194 at [29] per Bathurst CJ, McColl JA at [33] & Bergin CJ in Eq at [34] agreeing.
A contrary order, permitting earlier enforcement of a costs order relating to an interlocutory application, may be appropriate in the following circumstances:

where the interlocutory proceedings relate to matters distinct from the substantive issues in the proceedings: Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWCA 21 February 1996, unreported, BC9600215); Jazabas Pty Ltd v Haddad [2006] NSWSC 880; BC200607255 (security for costs application);

where the costs have been incurred as a result of unreasonable conduct by the party against whom the order has been made: Fiduciary Ltd v Morningstar Research Pty Ltd (2002) 55 NSWLR 1; [2002] NSWSC 432; BC200202544 ;

where the costs are significant and the time for payment may otherwise be long postponed because of the state of the proceedings: Fiduciary Ltd v Morningstar Research Pty Ltd (2002) 55 NSWLR 1; [2002] NSWSC 432; BC200202544 ; Royal Australian Naval Reserve Rifle Club Inc v NSW Rifle Association Inc [2010] NSWSC 351; BC201002509 (appears to be a long time before proceedings will be disposed of; plaintiff is impecunious — limited resources substantially diverted to contesting security for costs application on which it succeeded);

where the interlocutory proceeding was an unnecessary and unwarranted application having the effect of reducing the defendant’s financial capacity to defend the main proceedings: Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd v McAndrew [2008] NSWSC 790; BC200806956 (application for summary judgment “doomed to failure”, Contract Review Act defence and defendant suffering cognitive impairment);

where the costs order is relevant to a discreet , separately identifiable aspect of the proceedings: Hamod v NSW [2007] NSWSC 707; BC200705345 at [12], [13] (costs arising from unsuccessful discovery appeal — costs liability unaffected by final outcome of proceedings); Richards v Kadian (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 373; BC200509269 at [6]–[7] (costs arising from an unsuccessful application for leave to appeal — costs payable forthwith); Traderight (NSW) Pty Ltd v Bank of Queensland Ltd (No 2) [2008] NSWSC 589; BC200804390 at [7] (unsuccessful strike out application — costs payable forthwith); Chinese Australian Services Society Co-operative Ltd v Sham-Ho [2012] NSWSC 241; BC201201448 at [18] and following (costs order made against solicitors — solicitor’s role at an end — costs payable forthwith); Re Australian Property Custodian Holdings Ltd (in liq) (recs and mgrs apptd) (No 2) [2012] NSWSC 881; BC201206328 (costs of interlocutory process payable forthwith — party successful in application to strike out statement of claim — costs not otherwise payable for substantial period);

where there is disparity between the parties’ ability to bear ongoing costs: Traderight (NSW) Pty Ltd v Bank of Queensland Ltd (No 2) [2008] NSWSC 589; BC200804390 at [8] (bank in a better position than plaintiffs to bear the ongoing costs of litigation until its conclusion);
Matters in the Commercial List and the Technology and Construction List: Practice Note SC Eq 3 at para 57.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.8] r 42.8 Dispute of fact subsequently proved or admitted

leg:heading.title: Dispute of fact subsequently proved or admitted

p.text: In this rule:
means the party who serves a notice disputing a fact under rule 17.3 (2).
means the fact that is the subject of a notice served under rule 17.3 (2).
means the party who is served with a notice disputing a fact under rule 17.3 (2).

Unless the court orders otherwise, the disputing party must, after the conclusion of proceedings in which a fact in dispute is subsequently proved or is subsequently admitted by the disputing party, pay the requesting party’s costs, assessed on an indemnity basis, being costs incurred by the requesting party:
in proving the fact, or
if the fact has not been proved — in preparation for the purpose of proving the fact.
An entitlement to costs under this rule is not affected by any order as to costs unless that order makes particular reference in that regard.
[r 42.8 subst ; Amendment 7 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[9], effective 10 March 2006]
Legislation cited in [42.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 s 353.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.16(3).

The rule appears to create an automatic entitlement to costs in favour of the party who proves the disputed facts. Notwithstanding that automatic entitlement, a party who relies upon the present rule should obtain a specific order. In the absence of such an order difficulties may well arise in enforcing the entitlement to costs — because the assessment provision in s 353 of the Legal Profession Act 2004 relate to the assessment of costs payable pursuant to an order. If an appropriate order has not been sought at the time of final judgment UCPR r 36.16(3) would appear to confer power to have an appropriate order made subsequently.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.9] r 42.9 Dispute of authenticity of document subsequently proved or admitted

leg:heading.title: Dispute of authenticity of document subsequently proved or admitted

p.text: In this rule:
means a party who serves a notice disputing the authenticity of a document under rule 17.4(2) or 17.5(3).
means a document that is the subject of a notice served under rule 17.4(2) or 17.5(3).
means a party who is served with a notice disputing the authenticity of a document under rule 17.4(2) or 17.5(3).

Unless the court orders otherwise, the disputing party must, after the conclusion of proceedings in which the authenticity of a document in dispute is subsequently proved or is subsequently admitted by the disputing party, pay the requesting party’s costs, assessed on an indemnity basis, being costs incurred by the requesting party:
in proving the authenticity of the document, or
if the authenticity of the document has not been proved — in preparation for the purpose of proving the authenticity of the document.
An entitlement to costs under this rule is not affected by any order as to costs unless that order makes particular reference in that regard.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.10] r 42.10 Disobedience to rule, judgment, order or direction (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 25; DCR Part 39A, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Disobedience to rule, judgment, order or direction (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 25; DCR Part 39A, rule 4)

p.text: If a party fails to comply with a requirement of these rules, or of any judgment or order of the court, the court may order the party to pay such of the other parties’ costs as are occasioned by the failure.

Unless the court orders otherwise, an order as to costs with respect to an interlocutory injunction that continues an earlier interlocutory injunction, with or without modification, is to include the costs of the earlier injunction.

In this rule, interlocutory injunction means an interlocutory injunction granted by the Supreme Court, and includes a temporary injunction granted by the District Court under section 140 of the District Court Act 1973.
